newsitem.title: HONG KONG: Shenzhen stocks end down on clampdown fears.
newsitem.headline: Shenzhen stocks end down on clampdown fears.

text.p: Worries over a possible government crackdown on China's soaring stock markets caused Shenzhen's A and B share indices to close sharply lower on Thursday, analysts said.

The domestic currency A share index plunged 31.87 points or 5.97 percent to end at 501.92 on turnover of 20.2 billion yuan, following a record high close of 533.78 points on Wednesday with turnover of 21.3 billion yuan.
The foreign currency B share index fell 6.13 points or 3.35 percent to 176.61 on turnover of HK$215.08 million, against Wednesday's HK$233.63 million.
"Talk of an imminent clampdown is swirling around the market, and trading is expected to be very volatile towards the end of the week," an analyst at China Guotai Securities said.
The A share index has surged 47 percent since the beginning of 1997 to Thursday's close, while the B index has risen 22 percent over the same period.
China's official securities newspapers have repeatedly called for strengthening risk controls.
"Investor jitters over recent strong A share gains affected the B share market," an analyst at J&A Securities said.
Upcoming B share offers also drained some funds from the B share market, analysts said.
"Many investors are selling in preparation for subscribing to the new share offerings," the J&A analyst said.

Pesticide maker Hubei Sanonda Co Ltd, Shandong Chenming Paper Holdings Ltd and Nanjing Posts & Telecommunications Equipment Co Ltd will each offer 100 million B shares for listing in Shenzhen this month.
However, analysts said they expect the three new stocks to perform well on their listing debuts, which will likely boost investor sentiment.
"Investors are snatching up new share issues, likening them to money trees," the J&A analyst said.
Most analysts said they were confident that the underlying trend remains bullish.

China's gross domestic product (GDP) is expected to grow 9.6 percent year-on-year in the first half of 1997, with retail price inflation seen at two percent, according to a recent forecast by the State Economic and Trade Commission.
"Unless the government comes out with harsh measures, I am quite confident that the (A and B) indices will rise significantly in the medium-term," the J&A analyst said.
Shenzhen Great Ocean Shipping Co Ltd was the worst performer in the B share market, dropping HK$0.28 or 7.41 percent to HK$3.50.
In the A share market, institutional investors dumped large capitalisation Shenzhen Development Bank towards the end of the session, analysts said.
The stock fell 4.21 yuan or 8.61 percent to 44.69 on volume of 49.2 million shares, making it the most actively traded A share.
